posts.name: Matt Whitlock
posts.cooked:
I registered on this site just to this request. I currently send low-priority messages to my girlfriend via Facebook since she doesn’t have Messenger installed and only periodically checks her Facebook messages while she’s otherwise idle. I would strongly prefer to send her everything by Signal, which we do use for conversations, but I don’t want to bother her with my low-priority messages.

I wish Signal would give me a way to send a message with a flag to tell the receiving end not to emit a notification upon receipt.

Matt, welcome. :-) There is a workaround, though it is a bit of a pain.

  • you currently have a 1-on-1 chat, Matt + GF, with default notifications (turned on)
  • tap NewGroup, then AddMember Matt + GF (again), maybe called “MattGF_Silent” and set the groupchat-avatar-pic to be you and her together (shushing-faces)
  • configure the mini-groupchat to have notifications that are less-invasive (this could be distinct for the different people… if you are a heavy sleeper you might set your handset to vibrate-only whereas if your girlfriend is a light sleeper she might set hers to completely muted)

Then when you want to send her something that will ding, send it in the 1-on-1 chat, and if you want to send her something without dinging, instead you would use the MattGF_Silent mini-groupchat. I’ve done this and it works reasonably well, as long as the people in the conversation are heavily utilizing signalapp on a daily basis.

This is just a workaround, not a real fix. Each person will have two conversation-list items, on your device you will see “GF” and then also “MattGF_Silent” somewhere else in the list, and on her device she will see “Matt” and then also “MattGF_Silent”. This can make conversations confusing if you are hopping back and forth from one to the other all the time. It helps to specialize the purpose… if you spend 90% of the time conversing in MattGF_Silent, and only use the 1-on-1 chat for “hey are you busy” type of queries, that tends to keep all the substantive conversation in one place. Alternatively, you can do the opposite, and spend most of the time in the 1-on-1 chat, but use the MattGF_Silent when you think the other person is busy (at work or asleep or whatever).

But yeah, in the long run I definitely want to see a “Send Silently” option so that I can push out a message which lets me control whether the recipient’s phone will ding, buzz, notification-popup, all of the above, none of the above, and so on. And I would also like to see a different feature-request, which is “SEND KLAXON” :-)

Telegram introduced such feature a while ago, Aug '19. Its called “Silent Messages”:

On a similar tone, Telegram has also added an option that will enable users to send a message without invoking a sound notification at the recipient’s end. “Simply hold the Send button to have any message or media delivered without sound,” the app maker said. “Your recipient will get a notification as usual, but their phone won’t make a sound – even if they forgot to enable the Do Not Disturb mode.”

posts.cooked:
I would like to chime in here and offer some more points to this feature request.

How would it work?
Telegram has this feature, and the GIF below gives us a very good idea of how something like this could be implemented. Basically, the sender would have the option to long press on the send button, choose silent message, and then the message would send like a normal message, but it would not make a sound on the receiver’s device, even if they have notification sounds enabled. (More info here)

1f1728733cfa283b7a960×346 25.4 KB

What would this feature be for?
Being able to send silent messages to people would be incredibly useful for a number of reasons. If you want to tell someone something before you forget it, but you don’t want to disturb them for any reason, then you could simply send a silent message. If the person you’re talking to has gone to bed and you want to leave them a nice good morning message without waking them up, then you could do so with a silent message. This would be especially useful in long distance relationships where people are often in different time zones. I’m sure there are also a lot of other use cases for this feature.

This would be an excellent feature to have, and one that would make Signal stand out from others like Messenger or Instagram.
